articles.headline: G.O.P. Health Bill Faces Revolt From Conservative Forces
articles.snippet: Before the bill has even reached House committees, conservative senators and groups have come out against the plan to replace the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: Before the bill has even reached House committees, conservative senators and groups have come out against the plan to replace the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After seven years of waiting longingly to annul President Barack Obama’s signature health care law, Republican leaders on Tuesday faced a sudden revolt from the right that threatened their proposal to remake the American health care system.

articles.headline: Before Elections, Dutch Fear Russian Meddling, but Also U.S. Cash
articles.snippet: American conservative activists are supporting Europe’s far-right figures like Geert Wilders, who are campaigning against the European Union.
articles.abstract: American conservative activists are supporting Europe’s far-right figures like Geert Wilders, who are campaigning against the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — The parochial world of Dutch elections is not often seen as a hotbed of foreign intrigue. But in recent months, an unexpected worry has emerged: the influence of American money.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Christopher F. Schuetze

articles.headline: U.S. Zeal in Suing Banks for Lending Bias Is Expected to Cool
articles.snippet: The new administration’s deregulatory fervor has stirred expectations for a pullback in the enforcement of laws that prevent discrimination in lending.
articles.abstract: The new administration’s deregulatory fervor has stirred expectations for a pullback in the enforcement of laws that prevent discrimination in lending.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A week before President Obama left office, the Justice Department sued a Minnesota community bank, saying it failed to offer enough loans to people in minority neighborhoods in the Twin Cities area.

articles.headline: Trump Aides Address His Wiretap Claims: ‘That’s Above My Pay Grade’
articles.snippet: The president’s team has been uncharacteristically muted when pressed about Mr. Trump’s explosive and unproven accusations about President Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: The president’s team has been uncharacteristically muted when pressed about Mr. Trump’s explosive and unproven accusations about President Barack Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has no regrets. His staff has no defense.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Caterpillar Is Accused in Report to Federal Investigators of Tax Fraud
articles.snippet: The report outlines a strategy for bringing home billions of dollars from offshore affiliates while avoiding federal income taxes on the earnings.
articles.abstract: The report outlines a strategy for bringing home billions of dollars from offshore affiliates while avoiding federal income taxes on the earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, federal investigators have been scrutinizing Caterpillar’s overseas tax affairs with no resolution to the examinations of the complex maneuvers involving billions of dollars and one of the company’s Swiss subsidiaries.

articles.headline: North Korea Tensions Pose Early, and Perilous, Test for Trump
articles.snippet: The North’s provocations and Chinese anger over the deployment of a missile defense system in South Korea are creating a difficult balancing act for the new administration.
articles.abstract: The North’s provocations and Chinese anger over the deployment of a missile defense system in South Korea are creating a difficult balancing act for the new administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the United States began deploying a missile defense system in South Korea this week, it was to protect an ally long threatened by North Korean provocations. But it was instantly met by angry Chinese warnings that the United States is setting off a new arms race in a region already on edge over the North’s drive to build a nuclear arsenal.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Choe Sang-Hun, Chris Buckley and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Snap Makes a Bet on the Cultural Supremacy of the Camera
articles.snippet: Our rising dependence on cameras is changing our language, and the company behind Snapchat is counting on the eventual dominance of visual culture.
articles.abstract: Our rising dependence on cameras is changing our language, and the company behind Snapchat is counting on the eventual dominance of visual culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re watching Snap’s stock ticker, stop. The company that makes Snapchat, the popular photo-messaging app, has been having a volatile few days after its rocket-fueled initial public offering last week.

articles.headline: In Puerto Rico, Teachers’ Pension Fund Works Like a Ponzi Scheme
articles.snippet: The fund is so cash-short that contributions by younger teachers flow straight to retirees, and the working teachers can’t expect to get any money back.
articles.abstract: The fund is so cash-short that contributions by younger teachers flow straight to retirees, and the working teachers can’t expect to get any money back.
articles.lead_paragraph: The teachers’ pension fund in Puerto Rico looks very much like a legalized Ponzi scheme — one that might hold a warning for teachers across America.

articles.headline: Ethics Questions Dogged Agriculture Nominee as Georgia Governor
articles.snippet: Sonny Perdue, one of the last Trump cabinet picks awaiting confirmation, had 13 ethics complaints filed against him and was fined while he was governor.
articles.abstract: Sonny Perdue, one of the last Trump cabinet picks awaiting confirmation, had 13 ethics complaints filed against him and was fined while he was governor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Sonny Perdue’s telling, Georgians were growing weary of the corruption and scandals in their state when he took over as governor in 2003 — a time when he gave his own version of a “drain the swamp” pledge.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Steve Eder
